# General Electric (GE) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

General Electric Company (GE) has completed its multi-year transformation in 2024 by splitting into three independent, publicly traded companies: GE HealthCare, GE Vernova, and the current legal successor, GE Aerospace. GE Aerospace (NYSE: GE) is a global aerospace leader in attractive propulsion, services and systems sectors with an installed base of more than 44,000 commercial and over 26,000 military aircraft engines. At the same time, our global team of 52,000 employees are building on more than a century of innovation and learning to live our purpose: to invent the future of flight, lift people up, and bring them home safely.

The company focuses entirely on designing, manufacturing, and servicing commercial and military aircraft engines and their components. Engines made by GE Aerospace and its joint venture partners power three out of every four commercial flights around the world and two of three U.S. military combat and helicopter aircraft.

## 2. Current Market Data

GE Aerospace stock is trading at $326.58 (+0.71%) with a market cap (intraday) of $346.318B and a 52-week range of $159.36 - $329.43. The company has a trailing P/E of 42.88, forward P/E of 44.84, and a profit margin of 18.34%. The stock has earnings per share (TTM) of $7.49 with earnings date on January 22, 2026.

## 3. Existing Products/Services

### Commercial Engines & Services
- CFM International (50/50 joint venture with Safran) holds 39% of the world's commercial aircraft engine market share (while GE Aerospace itself holds a further 14%)
- CFM LEAP engines - high-bypass turbofan engines that use 15% less fuel and produce 15% less CO₂ compared to the CFM56
- GEnx engines with over 62 million flight hours logged and over 3,600 sales
- GE9X - the largest and most powerful commercial aircraft engine ever built, with a world record 134,300 pounds of thrust to power the 777X

### Defense & Propulsion Technologies
- F404, F414, T700, and CFE738 engines for military applications
- CF34 regional jet engine, CT7 commercial turboprop power plant, and commercial versions of the T700 turboshaft

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

### Advanced Engine Development
- CFM Revolutionary Innovation for Sustainable Engines (RISE) program targeting more than 20% lower fuel consumption and CO2 emissions, with plans to demonstrate Open Fan engine architecture
- NASA awarded GE Aerospace Phase 2 of the Hybrid Thermally Efficient Core (HyTEC) program for next generation commercial aircraft engines to significantly improve fuel efficiency and reduce emissions

### Hybrid Electric & Sustainable Aviation
- Strategic partnership with BETA Technologies to develop a hybrid electric turbogenerator for advanced air mobility (AAM) applications, including long-range vertical takeoff and landing (VTOL) aircraft
- Electrified Powertrain Flight Demonstration (EPFD) program with Boeing for ground and flight tests of hybrid electric systems using a modified Saab 340B aircraft

### Autonomous Flight Development
- Partnership with Merlin to pursue autonomy core development, combining GE's Flight Management System expertise with Merlin's autonomy software to unlock new capabilities for next-generation autonomous flight

## 5. Growth Strategy

GE Aerospace plans to invest nearly $1 billion in its U.S. factories and supply chain in 2025, nearly double last year's commitment, and will hire around 5,000 U.S. workers including both manufacturing and engineering roles. The company is growing capacity especially for CFM LEAP engine production, where deliveries are expected to increase by 15-20% this year, supported by their FLIGHT DECK lean operating model.

## 6. Current and Potential Major Clients

### Major Airline Customers
- Qatar Airways signed agreement for more than 400 engines, including 60 GE9X and 260 GEnx engines - the largest widebody engine purchase in GE Aerospace history
- Emirates agreement for 130 GE9X engines
- Strategic agreements with Saudia and flydubai
- Air India placed firm order for 20 777-9s powered by GE9X engines

### Defense Customers
- U.S. Army contract valued up to $1.1 billion for continued production of T700 engines through 2029
- GE Aerospace awarded $1.42B Navy contract modification

## 7. Financial Data & Performance

### Q4 2024 Results
GE Aerospace announced Q4 2024 results with fourth quarter orders up 46%, EPS more than doubling, and free cash flow increasing over 20%. The company reported revenue up double digits, profit up $1.7 billion, and free cash flow up $1.3 billion for full year 2024.

### Financial Metrics
- For the full year 2024, total revenue was $38.7 billion
- Returned more than $6 billion to shareholders in 2024, and announced share repurchase plans of $7 billion in 2025, while increasing the dividend by 30%
- Revenue (ttm) $43.95B, Net Income Available to Common (ttm) $8.05B

## 8. Market Shares

Within the aircraft engine industry, GE leads the market with a 55% share, followed by Pratt & Whitney at 26% and Rolls-Royce at 18%. However, when breaking down by segments:

- CFM International (GE's joint venture) holds 39% of the world's commercial aircraft engine market share while GE Aerospace itself holds a further 14%
- CFM International provides 71 percent of the global narrowbody aircraft engine market as of May 2019
- In the widebody aircraft engine market, General Electric Aviation is followed by Rolls-Royce, with 30 percent of the global market share

## 9. Comparison to Competitors

### Market Position
Together with CFM International, GE Aerospace claims to power three out of every four commercial flights, supporting both narrowbody and widebody programs with CFM powering the A320neo and 737 MAX, while GE has the 787 Dreamliner and 777X.

### Competitive Advantages
- Pratt & Whitney's reputation has been hit by ongoing problems with its GTF engines, despite securing over 1,100 engine orders in the first half of 2025
- Rolls-Royce currently powers around one-third of the global widebody fleet but has had a tough time since the pandemic

## 10. Partnerships, Mergers and Acquisitions

### Key Joint Ventures & Partnerships
- CFM International - 50/50 joint venture with French company Safran Aircraft Engines, the world's leading supplier of aircraft engines
- $300 million equity investment in BETA Technologies, subject to regulatory approval

### Strategic Collaborations
- Partnership with NASA for more than 50 years to accelerate aviation industry innovations
- Plans with Boeing, NASA, and Oak Ridge National Laboratory to model integration of Open Fan engine design

## 11. Recent Developments

### Production & Manufacturing Investments
- £19 million investment over three years to refurbish Nantgarw, Wales facility for MRO operations - the largest single investment at the Wales site in over two decades
- $53 million to upgrade the West Jefferson facility in the U.S.

### Supply Chain Improvements
- Material input improved 26% across priority supplier sites, supporting Commercial Engines & Service (CES) services revenue growing 17% and total engine units growing 18% in the second half of 2024

### Challenges
- Boeing postponed first delivery of 777X aircraft to 2027 after updating certification timing, making the program now late by seven years
- Flight tests were temporarily suspended in late November 2025 while GE Aerospace and Boeing investigated engine anomaly issues

## 12. AI Investment Rating & Fair Value Assessment

### Analyst Consensus & Price Targets
The 10 analysts that cover GE Aerospace stock have a consensus rating of "Strong Buy" with an average price target of $319.3, ranging from $222 to $386. Citigroup initiated coverage with a "Buy" recommendation and price target of $386. GE Aerospace has an average rating of overweight and mean price target of $346 according to analysts polled by FactSet.

### Investment Strengths
- Dominant market position with 55% aircraft engine market share
- Strong financial performance with double-digit revenue and profit growth
- Robust aftermarket services business with high margins
- Strategic investments in sustainable aviation and hybrid electric technologies
- Strong order backlog and long-term customer relationships

### Investment Risks
- Boeing 777X delays affecting GE9X program revenue
- Supply chain constraints impacting LEAP engine deliveries
- High valuation metrics with trailing P/E of 42.88
- Cyclical exposure to airline industry health and aircraft demand

### AI Investment Rating: 8/10 (Strong Buy)

**Rationale**: GE Aerospace demonstrates exceptional market leadership, strong financial fundamentals, and strategic positioning in next-generation aviation technologies. The company's transformation into a pure-play aerospace entity has unlocked significant value, supported by robust aftermarket services and innovative product development. While near-term headwinds from Boeing delays and supply chain issues exist, the long-term growth trajectory appears compelling.

### Estimated Fair Value: $350-365

**Based on**: Strong analyst consensus, dominant market position, growing services revenue, strategic technology investments, and premium valuation supported by market leadership and innovation pipeline. The fair value reflects the company's ability to capitalize on aviation recovery and sustainable aviation trends while managing near-term operational challenges.
